SP.L: Ha! sure some powerful sympathy directs
Us both—

SP.SPEAKER: JUSTICE.
SP.L: What is thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: SON.
SP.L: My name's TOM JENKINS—alias, have I none—
Tho' orphan'd, and without a friend!

SP.SPEAKER: JUSTICE.
SP.L: Thy parents?
son.
My father dwelt in Rochester—and was,
As I have heard—a fishmonger—no more.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF
SP.P: What, Sir, do you leave out the account of your birth, parentage and education?

SP.SPEAKER: SON.
SP.P: They have settled it so, Sir, here.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Oh! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.L: How loudly nature whispers to my heart!
Had he no other name?

SP.SPEAKER: SON.
SP.L: I've seen a bill
Of his, sign'd Tomkins, creditor.

SP.SPEAKER: JUSTICE.
SP.L: This does indeed confirm each circumstance
The gypsey told!—Prepare!

SP.SPEAKER: SON.
SP.L: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: JUSTICE.
SP.L: No orphan, nor without a friend ar't thou—
I am thy father, here's thy mother, there
Thy uncle—this thy first cousin, and those
Are all your near relations!

SP.SPEAKER: MOTHER.
SP.L: O ecstasy of bliss!

SP.SPEAKER: SON.
SP.L: O most unlook'd for happiness!

SP.SPEAKER: JUSTICE.
SP.L: O wonderful event!
SP.STAGE: [They faint alternately in each others arms.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: There, you see relationship, like murder, will out.

SP.SPEAKER: JUSTICE.
SP.L: Now let's revive—else were this joy too much!
But come—and we'll unfold the rest within,
And thou my boy must needs want rest and food.
Hence may each orphan hope, as chance directs,
To find a father—where he least expects!

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: What do you think of that?

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: One of the finest discovery-scenes I ever saw. —Why, this under-plot would have made a tragedy itself.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Aye, or a comedy either.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: And keeps quite clear you see of the other.
SP.STAGE: Enter SCENEMEN, taking away the Seats.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: The scene remains, does it?

SP.SPEAKER: SCENEMAN.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P:
You are to leave one chair you know—But it is always awkward in a tragedy, to have you
fellows coming in in your playhouse liveries to remove things—I wish that could be managed better.—So now for my mysterious yeoman.

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.P: Perdition catch my soul but I do love thee.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Haven't I heard that line before?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: No, I fancy not—Where pray?

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: Yes, I think there is something like it in Othello.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Gad! now you put me in mind on't, I believe there is—but that's of no consequence—all that can be said is, that two people happened to hit on the same thought—And Shakespeare made use of it first, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Very true.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Now, Sir, your soliloquy—but speak more to the pit, if you please—the soliloquy always to the pit—that's a rule.

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: Tho' hopeless love finds comfort in despair,
It never can endure a rival's bliss!
But soft—I am observ'd. [Exit Beefeater.

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: That's a very short soliloquy.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Yes—but it would have been a great deal longer if he had not been observed.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: A most sentimental Beefeater that, Mr. Puff.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Hearke—I would not have you be too sure that he is a Beefeater.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: What! a hero in disguise?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: No matter—I only give you a hint—But now for my principal character—Here he comes—LORD BURLEIGH in person! Pray, gentlemen, step this way—softly—I only hope the Lord High Treasurer is perfect—if he is but perfect!
SP.STAGE: [Enter BURLEIGH, goes slowly to a chair and sits.]

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Mr. Puff!

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Hush!—vastly well, Sir! vastly well! a most interesting gravity!

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: What, isn't he to speak at all?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P:
Egad, I thought you'd ask me that—yes it is a very likely thing—that a Minister in his situa∣tion,
with the whole affairs of the nation on his head, should have time to talk!—but hush! or you'll put him out.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Put him out! how the plague can that be, if he's not going to say any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: There's a reason!—why, his part is to think, and how the plague! do you imagine he can think if you keep talking?

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: That's very true upon my word!
SP.STAGE: [Burleigh comes forward, shakes his head and exit.]

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: He is very perfect indeed—Now, pray what did he mean by that?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: You don't take it?

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: No; I don't upon my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Why, by that shake of the head, he gave you to understand that even tho' they had more justice in their cause and wisdom in their mea∣sures—yet, if there was not a greater spirit shown on the part of the people—the country would at last fall a sacrifice to the hostile ambi∣tion of the Spanish monarchy.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: The devil!—did he mean all that by shaking his head?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Every word of it—If he shook his head as I taught him.

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: Ah! there certainly is a vast deal to be done on the stage by dumb shew, and expression of face, and a judicious author knows how much he may trust to it.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: O, here are some of our old acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
SP.L: My niece, and your niece too!
By heav'n! there's witchcraft in't—He could not else
Have gain'd their hearts—But see where they approach;
Some horrid purpose low'ring on their brows!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.L: Let us withdraw and mark them.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: What is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P:
Ah! here has been more pruning!—but the fact is, these two young ladies are also in love with Don Whiskerandos.—Now, gentlemen, this scene
goes entirely for what we call SITUATION and STAGE EFFECT, by which the greatest applause may be obtained, without the assistance of lan∣guage, sentiment or character: pray mark!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st NIECE.
SP.L: Ellena here!
She is his scorn as much as I—that is
Some comfort still.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: O dear madam, you are not to say that to her face!—aside, ma'am, aside.—The whole scene is to be aside.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st NIECE.
SP.L: She is his scorn as much as I—that is
Some comfort still!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d NIECE.
SP.L: I know he prizes not Pollina's love,
But Tilburina lords it o'er his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st NIECE.
SP.L: But see the proud destroyer of my peace.
Revenge is all the good I've left.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d NIECE.
SP.L: He comes, the false disturber of my quiet.
Now vengeance do thy worst—
O hateful liberty—if thus in vain
I seek my Tilburina!

SP.SPEAKER: BOTH NIECES.
SP.L: And ever shalt!
SIR CHRISTOPHER AND SIR WALTER come forward.
Hold! we will avenge you.

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: Hold you—or see your nieces bleed.!
SP.STAGE: [The two nieces draw their two daggers to strike Whiskerandos, the two Uncles at the instant with their two swords drawn, catch their two nieces arms, and turn the points of their swords to Whiske∣randos, who immediately draws two daggers, and holds them to the two nieces' bosoms.]

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: There's situation for you!—there's an heroic group!—You see the ladies can't stab Whiske∣randos —he durst not strike them for fear of their uncles—the uncles durst not kill him, because of their nieces—I have them all at a dead lock!—for every one of them is afraid to let go first.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Why, then they must stand there for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: So they would, if I hadn't a very fine contri∣vance for't—Now mind—

SP.L: In the Queen's name I charge you all to drop
Your swords and daggers!

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: That is a contrivance indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Aye—in the Queen's name.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
SP.L: Come niece!

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: What's he, who bids us thus renounce our guard?

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: Thou must do more, renounce thy love!

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: Thou liest—base Beefeater!

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: Ha! Hell! the lie!
By heav'n thou'st rous'd the lion in my heart!
Off yeoman's habit!—base disguise!—off! off!
SP.STAGE: [Discovers himself, by throwing off his upper dress, and appearing in a very fine waistcoat.]
SP.L: Am I a Beefeater now?
Or beams my crest as terrible as when
In Biscay's Bay I took thy captive sloop.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: There, egad! he comes out to be the very Captain of the privateer who had taken Whis∣kerandos prisoner—and was himself an old lover of Tilburina's.

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: Admirably manag'd indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Now, stand out of their way.

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: I thank thee fortune! that hast thus bestow'd
A weapon to chastise this insolent.

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: I take thy challenge, Spaniard, and I thank
Thee Fortune too!—

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: That's excellently contrived!—it seems as if the two uncles had left their swords on purpose for them.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: No, egad, they could not help leaving them.

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: Vengeance and Tilburina!

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: Exactly so—
SP.STAGE: They fight—and after the usual number of wounds given, Whiskerandos falls.

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: O cursed parry!—that last thrust in tierce
Was fatal—Captain, thou hast fenced well!
And Whiskerandos quits this bustling scene
For all eter—

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: —nity—He would have added, but stern death
Cut short his being, and the noun at once!

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: O, my dear Sir, you are too slow, now mind me.—Sir, shall I trouble you to die again?

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.L: And Whiskerandos quits this bustling scene
For all eter—

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: —nity—He would have added—

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: No, Sir—that's not it—once more if you please—

SP.SPEAKER: WHISKERANDOS.
SP.P: I wish, Sir—you would practise this without me—I can't stay dying here all night.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Very well, we'll go over it by and bye—I must humour these gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.L: Farewell—brave Spaniard! and when next—

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Dear Sir, you needn't speak that speech as the body has walked off.

SP.SPEAKER: BEEFEATER.
SP.P: That's true, Sir—then I'll join the fleet.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: If you please.
Now, who comes on?
SP.STAGE: Enter GOVERNOR, with his hair properly disordered.

SP.SPEAKER: GOVERNOR.
SP.L: A hemisphere of evil planets reign!
And every planet sheds contagious phrensy!
My Spanish prisoner is slain! my daughter,
Meeting the dead corse borne along—has gone
Distract!
But hark! I am summon'd to the fort,
Perhaps the fleets have met! amazing crisis!
O Tilburina! from thy aged father's beard
Thou'st pluck'd the few brown hairs which time had left!

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Poor gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Yes—and no one to blame but his daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: And the planets—

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: True.—Now enter Tilburina!—

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Egad, the business comes on quick here.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—now she comes in stark mad in white satin.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Why in white satin?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: O Lord, Sir—when a heroine goes mad, she always goes into white satin—don't she, Dangle?

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: Always—it's a rule.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Yes—here it is— (looking at the book.) 'Enter Tilburina stark mad in white satin, and her confidant stark mad in white linen.'

DIV2.STAGE: Enter TILBURINA and CONFIDANT mad, according to custom.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: But what the deuce, is the confidant to be mad too?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: To be sure she is, the confidant is always to do whatever her mistress does; weep when she weeps, smile when she smiles, go mad when she goes mad.—Now madam confidant—but —keep your madness in the back ground, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: TILBURINA.
SP.L: The wind whistles—the moon rises—see
They have kill'd my squirrel in his cage!
Is this a grasshopper!—Ha! no, it is my
Whiskerandos—you shall not keep him—
I know you have him in your pocket—
An oyster may be cross'd in love!—Who says
A whale's a bird?—Ha! did you call, my love?
—He's here! He's there!—He's every where!
Ah me! He's no where!

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: There, do you ever desire to see any body madder than that?

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Never while I live!

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: You observed how she mangled the metre?

SP.SPEAKER: DANGLE.
SP.P: Yes—egad, it was the first thing made me suspect she was out of her senses.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: And pray what becomes of her?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: She is gone to throw herself into the sea to be sure—and that brings us at once to the scene of action, and so to my catastrophe—my sea-fight, I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: What, you bring that in at last?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Yes—yes—you know my play is called the Spanish Armada, otherwise, egad, I have no oc∣casion for the battle at all.—Now then for my magnificence!—my battle!—my noise!—and my procession!—You are all ready?

SP.SPEAKER: PROMPTER within.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Is the Thames drest?

SP.SPEAKER: THAMES.
SP.P: Here I am, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Very well indeed—See, gentlemen, there's a river for you!—This is blending a little of the masque with my tragedy—a new fancy you know—and very useful in my case; for as there must be a procession, I suppose Thames and all his tributary rivers to compliment Britannia with a fete in honor of the victory.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: But pray, who are these gentlemen in green with him.

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Those?—those are his banks.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: His banks?

SP.SPEAKER: PUFF.
SP.P: Yes, one crown'd with alders and the other with a villa!—you take the allusions?—but hey! what the plague! you have got both your banks on one side—Here Sir, come round—Ever while you live, Thames, go between your banks. (Bell rings.)—There, soh! now for't!—Stand aside my dear friends!—away Thames!
